poem:
The Traitor's Dance

In the circle of deceit,  
eyes cast like shadows—  
trust twists,  
a serpent on soft ground.  

"If you killed her,"  
whispers weave,  
unraveling the thread of  
charms.  

Lost amongst the faces—  
I am the unwelcome  
footnote.  
A game of whispers,  
where trust falters,  
and truth  
slips quietly away.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘You killed her!’: My 100% faithful attempt at Traitors Live Experience Things are not going well. Halfway through my attempt to play the real-life version of the smash-hit reality BBC reality TV show The Traitors, I realise something: I may be less charming than I’d hoped. “I don’t trust him,” intones a player to my left, scowling at my face as though she has just found it on the bottom of her shoe. “Yeah, he". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
